articles.headline: Should Free Markets Govern the Bond Rating Agencies?
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. has strict oversight of which companies, like Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, can rate corporate bonds, but that system isn’t working well.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. has strict oversight of which companies, like Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s, can rate corporate bonds, but that system isn’t working well.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a lot not to like in the Financial Choice Act, the deregulatory construct put forward by House Republicans on April 28. Dubbed by its creators the “alternative to the failed Dodd-Frank Act,” it aims to repeal the 2010 law’s prohibition against banks engaging in risky trading for their own accounts. It also seeks to gut the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, one of the more effective agencies in Washington.

articles.headline: To Lift Growth, Janet Yellen Says, Make It Easier for Women to Work
articles.snippet: The Fed chairwoman warned in a speech at Brown University that obstacles to women’s participation in the work force damage productivity in the United States.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairwoman warned in a speech at Brown University that obstacles to women’s participation in the work force damage productivity in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an unusually personal speech, Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said Friday that policies making it easier for women to work could significantly improve the nation’s economic growth.

articles.headline: Willing to Cook for Strangers, but Guests Are Harder to Find
articles.snippet: Social-dining services give chefs and others an opportunity to share food experiences out of their homes, but many potential guests remain wary.
articles.abstract: Social-dining services give chefs and others an opportunity to share food experiences out of their homes, but many potential guests remain wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a penthouse apartment in Manhattan’s Chinatown on a recent Monday night, Lisa Larsson chopped shiitake mushrooms and looked rather relaxed for someone about to host a 14-person dinner.

articles.headline: Macron Campaign Says It Was Target of ‘Massive’ Hacking Attack
articles.snippet: A trove of internal campaign documents was posted online, campaign staff for the French presidential candidate said.
articles.abstract: A trove of internal campaign documents was posted online, campaign staff for the French presidential candidate said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the eve of the most consequential French presidential election in decades, the staff of the centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron said late Friday that the campaign had been targeted by a “massive and coordinated” hacking operation, one with the potential to destabilize the nation’s democracy before voters go to the polls on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Aurelien Breeden, Sewell Chan and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Mixed Signals From Trump Worry Pro-Israel Hard-Liners
articles.snippet: Some of the president’s supporters worry that the White House is listening too closely to Arab and Palestinian arguments and diluting support for Israel’s government.
articles.abstract: Some of the president’s supporters worry that the White House is listening too closely to Arab and Palestinian arguments and diluting support for Israel’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump hosted Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, at the White House this week with all the usual bonhomie he displays for foreign leaders. Within hours, he wrote on Twitter that it had been “an honor,” adding, “Hopefully something terrific” would come out “between the Palestinians & Israel.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Measure on Pre-existing Conditions Energizes Opposition to Health Bill
articles.snippet: A blast of grass-roots energy against the Republican bill has been generated by a single clause, which Democrats have vowed to make a campaign issue.
articles.abstract: A blast of grass-roots energy against the Republican bill has been generated by a single clause, which Democrats have vowed to make a campaign issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the moment the Republican-controlled House of Representatives approved a plan to overhaul the health care system, an onslaught of opposition to the bill has been focused on a single, compact term: pre-existing conditions.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Inside VW’s Campaign of Trickery
articles.snippet: New details emerge in Volkswagen’s broad conspiracy to cover up a campaign aimed at deceiving pollution regulators.
articles.abstract: New details emerge in Volkswagen’s broad conspiracy to cover up a campaign aimed at deceiving pollution regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is adapted from “Faster, Higher, Farther: The Volkswagen Scandal” by Jack Ewing, the European economics correspondent for The New York Times based in Frankfurt. The book, to be published May 23 by W. W. Norton, reveals new details of a broad conspiracy within Volkswagen to cover up the fact that its cars were designed to deceive pollution regulators.

articles.headline: When That Feisty Neighbor Becomes the President
articles.snippet: As a businessman, Donald J. Trump peppered local officials in Florida with requests, and governments pushed back. Now, some approvals come more easily.
articles.abstract: As a businessman, Donald J. Trump peppered local officials in Florida with requests, and governments pushed back. Now, some approvals come more easily.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — For local officials here, it was one thing to spar with Donald J. Trump, the developer, over the height of his ficus hedges, the crowds at his Elton John concerts and the roar of jet engines over his private club, Mar-a-Lago.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Steve Eder

articles.headline: ‘No District Is Off the Table’: Health Vote Could Put House in Play
articles.snippet: House Republicans, already set to play defense in 2018 because of their unpopular president, must now contend with an energized, angry Democratic Party.
articles.abstract: House Republicans, already set to play defense in 2018 because of their unpopular president, must now contend with an energized, angry Democratic Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a suburban Chicago district, Kelly Mazeski, a breast cancer survivor, used the day of the vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act to announce her House candidacy, vowing to make Representative Peter Roskam pay for his vote “to make Americans pay more and get less for their health care.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Health Act Repeal Could Threaten U.S. Job Engine
articles.snippet: Jobs in health care have grown much faster than most other sectors in the last decade, but could be threatened by the insurance coverage losses if Obamacare were repealed.
articles.abstract: Jobs in health care have grown much faster than most other sectors in the last decade, but could be threatened by the insurance coverage losses if Obamacare were repealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Akron to Youngstown and Canton to Cleveland, as in cities and towns across the country, workers who once walked out of factories at the end of each shift now stream out of hospitals.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: France Chooses a Leader, and Takes a Step Into the Unknown
articles.snippet: In a deeply divided country, some ask whether either Emmanuel Macron or Marine Le Pen will have enough authority to actually govern.
articles.abstract: In a deeply divided country, some ask whether either Emmanuel Macron or Marine Le Pen will have enough authority to actually govern.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s presidential election on Sunday has already broken all kinds of barriers in a country whose politics seemed frozen for decades. The two candidates are outsiders. The political establishment has been elbowed aside. The tone of the race between the insurgents has shocked many for its raw anger and insolence.

articles.headline: Puerto Ricans Face ‘Sacrifice Everywhere’ on an Insolvent Island
articles.snippet: The territory, which filed for a kind of bankruptcy protection in the face of $123 billion in debt, has been gripped by a sense of gloom and anxiety.
articles.abstract: The territory, which filed for a kind of bankruptcy protection in the face of $123 billion in debt, has been gripped by a sense of gloom and anxiety.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Angel González, a retired schoolteacher facing a 10 percent cut to his pension, is beginning to wonder whether his three-person household will have to cut back to one cellphone and take turns using it.

articles.headline: Tempers Flare Over Removal of Confederate Statues in New Orleans
articles.snippet: The city has already taken down one monument, but crane companies in the region are receiving threats over the removal of three others.
articles.abstract: The city has already taken down one monument, but crane companies in the region are receiving threats over the removal of three others.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — For Malcolm Suber, the Confederate monuments that dot this Deep South city stand for white supremacy, pure and simple. Instead of just taking them down, Mr. Suber, an African-American activist and organizer, would like to see the city pass out sledgehammers and “let everybody take a whack — just like the Berlin Wall.”

articles.headline: Macron Decisively Defeats Le Pen in French Presidential Race
articles.snippet: Emmanuel Macron’s victory suggested that his call for a new centrist approach to politics had handily defeated the nationalism of Marine Le Pen.
articles.abstract: Emmanuel Macron’s victory suggested that his call for a new centrist approach to politics had handily defeated the nationalism of Marine Le Pen.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Emmanuel Macron, a youthful former investment banker, handily won France’s presidential election on Sunday, defeating the staunch nationalist Marine Le Pen after voters firmly rejected her far-right message and backed his call for centrist change.

articles.headline: Hackers Find Celebrities’ Weak Links in Their Vendor Chains
articles.snippet: Big entertainment companies have toughened the security of their computer networks. But often, their suppliers and collaborators are vulnerable.
articles.abstract: Big entertainment companies have toughened the security of their computer networks. But often, their suppliers and collaborators are vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December, hackers impersonating an executive at Interscope Records, the record label owned by Universal Music Group, managed to bypass all the latest in digital defenses with a simple email.

articles.headline: Candid, Comedic and Macabre YouTube Stars Feel an Advertising Pinch
articles.snippet: After companies began pulling ads because of concerns about content, some video creators who thought they had no reason to worry have seen their revenue plunge.
articles.abstract: After companies began pulling ads because of concerns about content, some video creators who thought they had no reason to worry have seen their revenue plunge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Wood sat on a chair inside a house in Hinsdale, N.Y., long rumored to be haunted. He had a Ouija board in his lap and was livestreaming the experience to a group of fans on YouTube.

articles.headline: Why Macron Won: Luck, Skill and France’s Dark History
articles.snippet: Emmanuel Macron’s victory brought joy from Europe’s political establishment, as he managed to stem the populist tide that has roiled the West.
articles.abstract: Emmanuel Macron’s victory brought joy from Europe’s political establishment, as he managed to stem the populist tide that has roiled the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French presidential runoff transcended national politics. It was globalization against nationalism. It was the future versus the past. Open versus closed.

articles.headline: In Discover, Snap Sees a Bright Spot as It Tries to Fend Off Facebook
articles.snippet: Some publishers are minting profits off Snapchat’s nascent media venture. And that’s helping Snap challenge its much larger rival.
articles.abstract: Some publishers are minting profits off Snapchat’s nascent media venture. And that’s helping Snap challenge its much larger rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Snapchat unveiled Discover, a place in the messaging app where media companies can publish original stories, one of the publishers that jumped to get onto the platform was the website Mashable.

articles.headline: A Republican Principle Is Shed in the Fight on Health Care
articles.snippet: To the dismay of many conservatives, Republicans have had to shift their focus to cutting, not ending, popular benefits of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: To the dismay of many conservatives, Republicans have had to shift their focus to cutting, not ending, popular benefits of the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As they take their victory lap for passing a bill that would repeal and replace much of the Affordable Care Act, President Trump and congressional Republicans have been largely silent about one of the most remarkable aspects of what their legislation would do: take a step toward dismantling a vast government entitlement program, something that has never been accomplished in the modern era.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Dismisses Members of Major Scientific Review Board
articles.snippet: A spokesman for the agency’s administrator said he would consider replacing the academic scientists with representatives from industries the agency is supposed to regulate.
articles.abstract: A spokesman for the agency’s administrator said he would consider replacing the academic scientists with representatives from industries the agency is supposed to regulate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency has dismissed at least five members of a major scientific review board, the latest signal of what critics call a campaign by the Trump administration to shrink the agency’s regulatory reach by reducing the role of academic research.

articles.headline: Ad Buyers Have a Say in Whether Real News Survives
articles.snippet: As online marketing continues to starve newspapers of revenue, Philadelphia’s newspapers test one way to stay viable and still do good journalism.
articles.abstract: As online marketing continues to starve newspapers of revenue, Philadelphia’s newspapers test one way to stay viable and still do good journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Hey, America’s Advertisers: You got some good news last week, didn’t you?

articles.headline: Emmanuel Macron Embraces E.U. to Put France ‘Back in the Picture’
articles.snippet: In his presidential campaign, Mr. Macron linked the future of France with the success of the European Union, but the bloc still faces several urgent problems.
articles.abstract: In his presidential campaign, Mr. Macron linked the future of France with the success of the European Union, but the bloc still faces several urgent problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a striking moment when Emmanuel Macron, newly elected president of France, torchbearer of a new politics, strode onto a courtyard of the Louvre to celebrate his victory: As the crowd cheered, waving the tricolor French flag, the choice of music was “Ode to Joy,” the anthem of the European Union. Some people even waved the bloc’s flag, with its circle of golden stars.

articles.headline: Coach’s $2.4 Billion Kate Spade Deal Aims at Weak Middle of Fashion Market
articles.snippet: Coach was once a leader in American retailing, and the deal is the latest in a series of acquisitions aimed at building an accessible luxury group.
articles.abstract: Coach was once a leader in American retailing, and the deal is the latest in a series of acquisitions aimed at building an accessible luxury group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coach and Kate Spade have long been the affordable luxury brands of choice for the aspirational shopper. From Coach’s embossed logo and leather handbags to Kate Spade’s kitschy, colorful accessories, their products lured buyers who wanted a taste of fashion without the sharpest edges — or the highest cost.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Paton, Vanessa Friedman and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: South Korea’s Powerful Family Business Ties Could Be Tough to Cut
articles.snippet: As voters select a new president, many seek to rein in the politically connected conglomerates known as chaebol — but the companies are adept at keeping power.
articles.abstract: As voters select a new president, many seek to rein in the politically connected conglomerates known as chaebol — but the companies are adept at keeping power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forget Machiavelli, or “Game of Thrones.” When it comes to staying in power, South Korea’s richest business clans have the game plan down.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Soble, Jeyup S. Kwaak and Choe Sang-Hun
